newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RBA'S Macfarlane says 1996 slowdown was very mild.
newsitem.headline: RBA'S Macfarlane says 1996 slowdown was very mild.

text.p: Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) governor Ian Macfarlane said on Thursday the bank had been successful in producing only a mild slowdown in economic growth in 1996.

Macfarlane, answering a question from former Labor treasurer Ralph Willis to a government committee, said the Reserve Bank's tightenings in 1994 had been sufficient to slow an initial sharp expansion to about three percent GDP growth in 1996.
"I think we've had a very mild mid-term slowing," Macfarlane told a federal parliamentary committee.
Willis had asked if the Reserve Bank's easings in 1996 should have been carried out earlier.
Macfarlane said he thought it was pointless to try and judge the Reserve Bank in hindsight.
"I think that's a Utopian expectation," he said.
Willis' Labor government was routed in the March 1996 election, just months before the Reserve Bank started its series of three policy easings in mid to late 1996.
